articles.headline: Dealer Fees for Arranging Car Loans Are Drawing Scrutiny From U.S.
articles.snippet: Consumer advocates and regulators are concerned that the ability of dealers to decide how much to charge for arranging a loan has led to discrimination.
articles.abstract: Consumer advocates and regulators are concerned that the ability of dealers to decide how much to charge for arranging a loan has led to discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:13 p.m. | When Pedro Lantigua, a 32-year-old truck driver from Oklahoma City, decided to trade in his vehicle last summer, he walked into his local dealership and drove off with a brand-new Chevrolet Silverado. Like millions of Americans, he agreed to a loan arranged by the dealer.

articles.headline: An Upscale Bounty, and a Thankful Shopper
articles.snippet: With competition in high-end supermarkets heating up, there’s never been a better time to shop for the Thanksgiving meal. But which store offers the best deal?
articles.abstract: With competition in high-end supermarkets heating up, there’s never been a better time to shop for the Thanksgiving meal. But which store offers the best deal?
articles.lead_paragraph: Since opening its first store in Austin, Tex., in 1980, Whole Foods Market has transformed the way Americans shop for food and eat at home — at least those who live in mostly affluent urban areas. When a branch opened in my neighborhood — theretofore a culinary desert — I wandered wide-eyed through what seemed a paradise of offerings tended by an eager and informed staff.

articles.headline: Choosing Child Care When You Go Back to Work
articles.snippet: A primer on what to expect on prices and tax breaks, as well as advice on how to approach the decision.
articles.abstract: A primer on what to expect on prices and tax breaks, as well as advice on how to approach the decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: The largest financial commitment that many new parents make is also the most emotional: choosing a full-time caregiver for your child as you head back to work.

articles.headline: Questions on Drone Strike Find Only Silence
articles.snippet: Faisal bin Ali Jaber, who lost two relatives in a drone strike, struggled to pierce a veil of secrecy and anonymity during a visit to Washington.
articles.abstract: Faisal bin Ali Jaber, who lost two relatives in a drone strike, struggled to pierce a veil of secrecy and anonymity during a visit to Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing on the marble floor just outside the House chamber, Faisal bin Ali Jaber looked lost in the human river of hard-charging lobbyists, members of Congress and staffers. It is not every day that a victim of American drone strikes travels 7,000 miles to Washington to look for answers.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Strong Rules on Fracking in Wyoming Seen as Model
articles.snippet: The state, a big energy producer, has enacted strong disclosure laws on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, to protect air and water quality.
articles.abstract: The state, a big energy producer, has enacted strong disclosure laws on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, to protect air and water quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: In energy-friendly Wyoming, oil and gas companies are getting a clear message: Drill, baby, drill — but carefully.

articles.headline: U.S. Retailers Decline to Aid Factory Victims in Bangladesh
articles.snippet: Walmart, Sears, Children’s Place and other American companies that were selling goods produced at the site of two disasters are not joining in efforts to compensate victims’ families.
articles.abstract: Walmart, Sears, Children’s Place and other American companies that were selling goods produced at the site of two disasters are not joining in efforts to compensate victims’ families.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year after the Tazreen factory fire in Bangladesh, many retailers that sold garments produced there or inside the Rana Plaza building that collapsed last spring are refusing to join an effort to compensate the families of the more than 1,200 workers who died in those disasters.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Report Outlined Goals for More Power
articles.snippet: The top-secret document described strategies to keep pace with rapidly changing technology and stay ahead of adversaries in intelligence collection.
articles.abstract: The top-secret document described strategies to keep pace with rapidly changing technology and stay ahead of adversaries in intelligence collection.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials at the National Security Agency, intent on maintaining its dominance in intelligence collection, pledged last year to push to expand its surveillance powers, according to a top-secret strategy document.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Laura Poitras

articles.headline: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
articles.snippet: President Obama’s critics — in Congress, the Arab world and Israel — argue that he has the strategy backward in negotiating a freeze of Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s critics — in Congress, the Arab world and Israel — argue that he has the strategy backward in negotiating a freeze of Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its delicate negotiations with Iran over freezing its nuclear program, the Obama administration is gambling that the gradual relaxation of punishing sanctions will whet Tehran’s appetite for greater economic relief, inducing the country’s leaders to negotiate a further deal to roll back its nuclear progress.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Tension and Flaws Before Health Website Crash
articles.snippet: Interviews and documents offer new details into how the rollout of President Obama’s signature program turned into a major humiliation.
articles.abstract: Interviews and documents offer new details into how the rollout of President Obama’s signature program turned into a major humiliation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a sultry day in late August, a dozen staff members of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services gathered at the agency’s Baltimore headquarters with managers from the major contractors building HealthCare.gov to review numerous problems with President’s Obama’s online health insurance initiative. The mood was grim.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Ian Austen and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Urbanites Flee China’s Smog for Blue Skies
articles.snippet: China is undergoing a surprising reverse migration: As millions leave to find work in the cities, some well-educated urban dwellers are relocating to small towns.
articles.abstract: China is undergoing a surprising reverse migration: As millions leave to find work in the cities, some well-educated urban dwellers are relocating to small towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALI, China — A typical morning for Lin Liya, a native of Shanghai transplanted to this ancient town in southwest China, goes like this: See her 3-year-old son off to school near the mountains; go for a half-hour run on the shores of Erhai Lake; and browse the local market for fresh vegetables and meat.

articles.headline: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
articles.snippet: The United States and five other world powers announced an accord that would temporarily freeze Tehran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping deal.
articles.abstract: The United States and five other world powers announced an accord that would temporarily freeze Tehran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States and five other world powers announced a landmark accord Sunday morning that would temporarily freeze Iran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping agreement.

articles.headline: $13 Billion, Yes, but What Took So Long?
articles.snippet: In reaching its big settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department seemed to rely largely on facts that have been known for years.
articles.abstract: In reaching its big settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department seemed to rely largely on facts that have been known for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of pre-deal chatter about its $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department finally nailed it down last week. And for the first time, the department provided a glimpse of the investigatory findings upon which the settlement was based.

articles.headline: For Chess, a Would-Be White Knight
articles.snippet: A colorful entrepreneur named Andrew Paulson wants to turn chess into the world’s next mass-market spectator sport, complete with commentators who dissect the action and show potential moves.
articles.abstract: A colorful entrepreneur named Andrew Paulson wants to turn chess into the world’s next mass-market spectator sport, complete with commentators who dissect the action and show potential moves.
articles.lead_paragraph: If chess were storytelling, Andrew Paulson would be the undisputed world champion, the Bobby Fischer of raconteurs.

articles.headline: Two Gunshots on a Summer Night
articles.snippet: The death of a woman in Florida, and the flawed investigation that ruled it a suicide, raise concerns about how police departments handle accusations of domestic violence that involve officers.
articles.abstract: The death of a woman in Florida, and the flawed investigation that ruled it a suicide, raise concerns about how police departments handle accusations of domestic violence that involve officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — News of the shooting arrived via police radio as Deputy Debra Maynard and two other officers were sipping late-night coffee at the Hess gas station, a brightly lit outpost on a slumbering stretch of Dixie Highway on St. Augustine’s south side.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Glenn Silber

articles.headline: In War for Same-Day Delivery, Racing Madly to Go Last Mile
articles.snippet: For all the sophisticated algorithms involved in same-day delivery, many of the services ultimately come down to the delivery guy.
articles.abstract: For all the sophisticated algorithms involved in same-day delivery, many of the services ultimately come down to the delivery guy.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a hot new job in tech: delivery guy.

articles.headline: Don’t Dare Call the Health Law ‘Redistribution’
articles.snippet: Redistribution is a toxic term at the White House, where it has become a target for Republicans, who have long accused Democrats of seeking “socialized medicine.”
articles.abstract: Redistribution is a toxic term at the White House, where it has become a target for Republicans, who have long accused Democrats of seeking “socialized medicine.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rebecca M. Blank was a top candidate in 2011 to lead President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, but then the White House turned up something politically dangerous.

articles.headline: Selling That New-Man Feeling
articles.snippet: Tired? Listless? Testosterone therapy is in fashion, but critics say it’s based on unclear science — and driven by marketing.
articles.abstract: Tired? Listless? Testosterone therapy is in fashion, but critics say it’s based on unclear science — and driven by marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon a few months ago, a 45-year-old sales representative named Mike called “The Dr. Harry Fisch Show,” a weekly men’s health program on the Howard Stern channel on Sirius XM Radio, where no male medical or sexual issue goes unexplored.

articles.headline: Disruptions: If It Looks Like a Bubble and Floats Like a Bubble …
articles.snippet: Though Silicon Valley insists there is not a technology bubble, average investors should be cautious, especially when many highly valued companies have yet to produce earnings.
articles.abstract: Though Silicon Valley insists there is not a technology bubble, average investors should be cautious, especially when many highly valued companies have yet to produce earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It sounds like heresy around here. But here goes:

articles.headline: Longer-Term Deal With Iran Faces Major Challenges
articles.snippet: The six-month interim plan agreed to over the weekend is intended to allow time to pursue a more comprehensive deal on Iran’s nuclear program, one that will require much tougher choices by each side.
articles.abstract: The six-month interim plan agreed to over the weekend is intended to allow time to pursue a more comprehensive deal on Iran’s nuclear program, one that will require much tougher choices by each side.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Obama administration’s successful push for an accord that would temporarily freeze much of Iran’s nuclear program has cast a spotlight on the more formidable challenge it now confronts in trying to roll the program back.

articles.headline: Once Cable’s King, Malone Aims to Regain His Crown
articles.snippet: John C. Malone, the chairman of Liberty Media, is working behind the scenes to gain control of Time Warner Cable, seeking a second act in an industry he once dominated.
articles.abstract: John C. Malone, the chairman of Liberty Media, is working behind the scenes to gain control of Time Warner Cable, seeking a second act in an industry he once dominated.
articles.lead_paragraph: John C. Malone made a fortune wiring American homes for cable television in the 1980s and 1990s. Known as the King of Cable, he sold TCI — once the country’s largest cable operator — to AT&T for $48 billion in 1999.

articles.headline: The Weinstein Company, Seeking Hits, Shifts to TV
articles.snippet: The heavy investment in the production and sale of TV series mirrors changes occurring elsewhere in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: The heavy investment in the production and sale of TV series mirrors changes occurring elsewhere in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Oscar season approaches fever pitch, Harvey Weinstein, master of the movie awards game, is talking about ... television.

articles.headline: Overlook the Value of Interns at Great Peril
articles.snippet: Some major publishers are dropping their unpaid internship programs in the face of complaints, but they might be missing the point.
articles.abstract: Some major publishers are dropping their unpaid internship programs in the face of complaints, but they might be missing the point.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, The New York Post ran the kind of heart-rending article tabloids excel at. A young woman, new to New York, found herself pushed beyond what she could bear, forced to work by a big bad corporation for a compensation of exactly zero.

articles.headline: Drones Offer Journalists a Wider View
articles.snippet: Remotely controlled aircraft have provided valuable images of events that are difficult to reach, including the recent typhoon in the Philippines.
articles.abstract: Remotely controlled aircraft have provided valuable images of events that are difficult to reach, including the recent typhoon in the Philippines.
articles.lead_paragraph: The best way to film the destruction wrought by Typhoon Haiyan in Tacloban, the Philippines, said Lewis Whyld, a British photographer, was from the air.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: In Bitcoin’s Orbit: Rival Virtual Currencies Vie for Acceptance
articles.snippet: Bitcoin is not alone. The virtual universe has spawned a few dozen alternatives, with varying reserves, computer mining requirements and privacy.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin is not alone. The virtual universe has spawned a few dozen alternatives, with varying reserves, computer mining requirements and privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many people, bitcoin seems like something from the day after tomorrow.

articles.headline: Signs of Change in News Mission at Bloomberg
articles.snippet: Bloomberg faces newsroom layoffs, a shift in emphasis back to financial news and skepticism from the business side that investigative journalism might not be worth the potential problems it could create for terminal sales.
articles.abstract: Bloomberg faces newsroom layoffs, a shift in emphasis back to financial news and skepticism from the business side that investigative journalism might not be worth the potential problems it could create for terminal sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Champagne flowed last Monday night as Hong Kong’s business elite gathered with top Bloomberg L.P. executives at a dinner for 100 guests at a cultural center in a former British colonial military complex.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick, Nathaniel Popper, Edward Wong and David Carr

articles.headline: Backlash by the Bay: Tech Riches Alter a City
articles.snippet: As the largess from tech companies has flowed into San Francisco, some residents say their workers are driving up housing prices and spoiling the city’s bohemian identity.
articles.abstract: As the largess from tech companies has flowed into San Francisco, some residents say their workers are driving up housing prices and spoiling the city’s bohemian identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If there was a tipping point, a moment that crystallized the anger building here toward the so-called technorati for driving up housing prices and threatening the city’s bohemian identity, it came in response to a diatribe posted online in August by a young Internet entrepreneur.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Nuclear Accord With Iran Opens Diplomatic Doors in the Mideast
articles.snippet: The preliminary accord reached with Iran is a seminal moment for President Obama, but experts say seeking a broader diplomatic opening could alter other American calculations.
articles.abstract: The preliminary accord reached with Iran is a seminal moment for President Obama, but experts say seeking a broader diplomatic opening could alter other American calculations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, whose popularity and second-term agenda have been ravaged by the chaotic rollout of the health care law, the preliminary nuclear deal reached with Iran on Sunday is more than a welcome change of subject.

articles.headline: Court Confronts Religious Rights of Corporations
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will decide whether to hear an Obama administration appeal of a lower court’s ruling that a company could restrict contraception insurance coverage.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will decide whether to hear an Obama administration appeal of a lower court’s ruling that a company could restrict contraception insurance coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hobby Lobby, a chain of crafts stores, closes on Sundays, costing its owners millions but honoring their Christian faith.
